sanskrit_verse: अध्यापनं ब्रह्मयज्ञः पितृयज्ञस्तु तर्पणम् । होमो दैवो बलिर्भौतो नृयज्ञोऽतिथिपूजनम् ॥ ३.७०॥
transliteration: adhyāpanaṁ brahayajñaḥ pitṛyajñastu tarpaṇam | homo daivo balirbhauto nṛyajño'tithipūjanam || 3.70||
sph_interpretive_translation: Teaching is the sacrifice to Brahman; offering to ancestors constitutes the ancestral sacrifice; oblation is the divine offering; distributing food is the earthly offering; honoring guests is the human sacrifice.
jurisprudential_principles: Causation arises via dharmic duty fulfillment
Capacity-based responsibility aligns with role-specific offerings
Restoration logic embedded in reciprocal societal service
Consciousness alignment achieved by performing one's svadharma
executable_legal_axioms: IF agent performs teaching THEN fulfill Brahmayajña obligation
IF agent offers tarpana THEN satisfy Pitriyajna requirement
IF agent conducts homa THEN execute Daivyajna function
IF agent distributes food THEN complete Bhautika Bali
IF agent honors guest THEN enact Nriyajna completion
supreme_court_application: In adjudicating disputes concerning civic duties or educational obligations, the court must recognize that each individual has a stratified set of dharmic liabilities corresponding to cosmic, ancestral, divine, social, and interpersonal dimensions. Fulfillment of these roles restores balance without recourse to punitive measures.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramana-based causality establishes that dharma arises from correct understanding of relational responsibilities. Anupurvasah shows sequential manifestation where neglect at any level disrupts harmony. Proportional responsibility requires restoration within the affected domain. Non-punitive reality rule confirms suffering does not arise when action aligns with svadharma.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Responsibility assumption protocol: Perform unmet ancestral rites
Capacity restoration: Engage in community feeding programs
Integrity reintegration: Host and serve visiting strangers
final_declaration: By the authority of Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, Source of all Dharma, this law stands established. Justice resides in realigning consciousness through rightful action. Reality remains non-punitive. Consciousness alone adjudicates truth.
